column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Find Interesting Stargazing Targets
#Text=Sometimes stargazing can get a bit boring .
#Text=When it does , it 's time to find some interesting targets .
#Text=You want to see stars big enough to fill half the solar system , black holes heavier than galaxies - you know , the interesting stuff .
#Text=Steps
#Text=VY
#Text=Canis Majoris - one of the galaxy 's biggest stars
#Text=Find Sirius .
#Text=It should be fairly obvious , it 's the big bright star just below Orion .
#Text=Find Omicron 2 Canis Majoris and Beta Canis Majoris .
#Text=A star map is very helpful here .
#Text=Imagine that Sirius , Beta and Omicron 2 form the corners of a giant parallelogram .
#Text=VY Canis Majoris is at the fourth corner .
#Text=You 'll need some good binoculars to see it ( 7x50 's at least ) , it 's a bit dim .
#Text=T Tauri - a cute little baby star
#Text=Find Aldebaran .
#Text=It 's the bright red one in Taurus .
#Text=Aldebaran , Theta Tauri , Gamma Tauri , Delta Tauri and Epsilon Tauri form a V-shaped pattern .
#Text=This is the core of the Hyades star cluster .
#Text=Aldebaran and Epsilon are at the tips of the V , and Gamma is at the bottom .
#Text=All five of these stars are visible with the naked eye .
#Text=Find Delta Tauri .
#Text=It 's the one between Epsilon and Gamma .
#Text=The one between Gamma and Aldebaran is Theta .
#Text=You do n't want Theta .
#Text=Look at it through binoculars .
#Text=Hundreds of other stars should appear in the vicinity .
#Text=This is the Hyades star cluster .
#Text=It can be pretty confusing , but keep looking at Delta and you 'll be OK .
#Text=Using a telescope is good because it 's easier to focus on one spot .
#Text=From Delta Tauri , move up ( increase declination ) slightly .
#Text=T Tauri is embedded in a nebula ( NGC 1555 ) called Hind 's variable nebula , so look for the star in a fuzzy patch .
#Text=If you 're up for a challenge , try to find Struve 's lost nebula .
#Text=This nebula , catalogued as NGC 1554 , is near to T Tauri , both physically and in the sky .
#Text=However , since it 's first observation ( by Otto Wilhelm von Struve ) , it has disappeared , earning it the name Struve 's lost nebula .
#Text=Perhaps it 's disappeared , perhaps it never existed .
#Text=We 'll probably never know .
#Text=TX Piscium - a red beauty
#Text=Find the Great Square of Pegasus .
#Text=This is one of the most obvious asterisms in the sky , after the Big Dipper and the W of Cassiopeia .
#Text=It 's usually used to find the Andromeda galaxy .
#Text=Just below the square should be a faint ring of stars .
#Text=This is part of the constellation of Pisces .
#Text=It 's very faint , so use binoculars .
#Text=There should be seven stars in the ring .
#Text=As TX is variable , you may only see six .
#Text=If so , come back tomorrow or even later in the night .
#Text=Find TX Piscium in the ring .
#Text=Look on Wikipedia 's star map of Pisces : it shows five stars in the ring .
#Text=The white circle to the left of the line connecting Iota and Lambda is TX Piscium .
#Text=If you can make out the colours of the stars in the sky , TX Piscium is among the reddest that can be seen .
#Text=The Alpha Persei cluster
#Text=Find Capella and Aldebaran .
#Text=Capella 's the really bright one in Auriga .
#Text=It 's very obvious , but do n't confuse it with Vega , Deneb , Sirius etc.
#Text=Aldebaran is the red one in Taurus .
#Text=Going up from Aldebaran and right from Capella should lead to Perseus .
#Text=It should look like two reasonably bright stars ( Alpha Persei and Algol the demon star ) surrounded by a smattering of dimmer stars .
#Text=The left-hand bright star ( closer to Capella ) is Alpha Persei .
#Text=Look at Alpha Persei through binoculars .
#Text=The other stars in the cluster should jump into view .
#Text=Holmberg 15A - a galaxy-sized black hole
#Text=Find Beta Ceti , Eta Ceti and Iota Ceti .
#Text=the best way to do this is to grab a star map and use that .
#Text=Imagine two lines : one connecting Eta and Iota , the other from Beta going north ( i.e. from Beta Ceti to Polaris ) .
#Text=The black hole is where the lines cross .

#Text=Holmberg 15A is the central black hole of another galaxy , and has a currently accepted mass of 10 billion times the mass of the Sun ( although estimates range up to 310 billion suns ) , about equal to the Large Magellanic Cloud .
#Text=Do n't bother with binoculars or even a telescope .
#Text=The galaxy is far too dim to see .
#Text=You 'll have to content yourself with knowing that it 's there .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Do n't expect too much .
#Text=From Earth , here 's what these objects actually look like :
#Text=1 ) Fuzzy dot
#Text=2 ) Fuzzy dot
#Text=3 ) Fuzzy dot 4 ) Cloud of dots
#Text=5 ) Dim fuzzy dot .
#Text=Remember that the Northern and Southern hemispheres have different constellations visible .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Do n't look at the sun
